awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Knowledge Work and Coordination to Improve O&M and IT Collaboration to Keep Our Buildings Smart AND Secure
awd_abstract_narration:
Government organizations, businesses, and universities are increasingly adding Internet of Things (IoT) devices, such as room occupancy sensors, into their buildings. As these sensors are connected to the internet and networked to building technology (such as heating and lights), an attacker could shut down a building or steal sensitive information. While technical solutions exist, implementation of these solutions are impeded by the challenges that an organization's information technology (IT) staff and a building's operations and management (O&M) staff have when they fail to work closely together and share their knowledge about computer security and how buildings operate. These difficulties arise from different ways of working and different points of view about how technology works. This project addresses these challenges through studying two critical areas: (1) how O&M and IT currently share their knowledge and skills and work together to improve IoT security and (2) how public policies and an organization's own rules regarding privacy and security impact how IT and O&M collaborate. The results of this study will generate knowledge around how IT and O&M professionals can work better together to improve the security of our nation's buildings and offer insights into how public policy may affect professional cybersecurity collaboration.

This project will identify how legal and organizational policies and procedures interact with daily work practices to either support or limit how O&M and IT staff share their expertise and coordinate their work to collaborate on IoT security issues. The research team will conduct observations, interviews, and document analyses, first observing and interviewing IT and O&M staff on collaborative cybersecurity efforts in three U.S. universities and analyzing university documents related to IoT cybersecurity. The research team will concurrently conduct interviews with IT and O&M security experts from across the U.S. as well as create a set of comparative case studies of university O&M and IT IoT security efforts. This research will be followed by a final set of expert interviews. The research team will identify key methods that support IT and O&M collaboration and develop a theoretical model to provide a holistic view of how organization, policy, and practice interact and affect collaboration intended to keep IoT safe and secure. This research will also provide clear examples of how policies, procedures, and  practices used in organizations today are supporting or impeding collaboration between IT and O&M professionals.

por.por_cntn:
As Internet of Things (IoT) devices are increasing in the buildings where we live and work, cybersecurity risks also increase. This project sought to improve IoT cybersecurity in the built environment through uncovering the challenges that operations staff face when information technology (IT) and facilities managers need to work together in new ways. These challenges create some of the most intractable cybersecurity risks and are shaped by organizational practices as well as IoT public policy. We not only contributed to cybersecurity and organizational research, but have made broader impacts that help facilities and IT staff work better together on smart building cybersecurity, educate policymakers on the challenges building owners face with smart building cybersecurity, and educate smart building owners about current and future IoT policies.

We discovered that on higher education campuses, there were many pathways for IoT to enter a campus through different departments, staff, faculty, and students. (See Figure 1.)

For IT and facilities staff, smart building IoT cybersecurity challenges occurred in three main areas: in the Design and Construction (D&C) process, in processes for purchasing IoT from vendors for building systems, and in the daily work of building operations. 

During D&C, there are few standardized processes that provide opportunities for IT and facilities professionals to engage or consult on new construction and renovation projects. D&C teams often do not meet with IT and facilities specialists until late in construction or after tenants begin to move into a building. This means that potential problems with cybersecurity are often discussed only after it is too late to mitigate security risks. (see Figure 2.)

During vendor procurement, there is a lack of clear cybersecurity criteria and standards for IoT devices and systems, few policies that clarify who is responsible for IoT security updates, and cybersecurity specialists are often not consulted early enough when D&C or facilities teams are going through the purchasing process. The research literature and our conversations with practitioners indicates that this is not unique to universities but common to any complex organization that manages a large number of facilities.

When operating buildings and infrastructure, the disciplinary divide between IT and facilities professionals creates challenges with determining who is responsible for the smart building networks that IoT devices are connected to. There are also communication and cultural issues that can make it difficult to get IT and facilities personnel to work together to improve cybersecurity.

Despite these challenges, we found that many universities were working hard to find solutions to these problems. We developed recommendations based on the challenges we learned, as well as the solutions that some universities have put into place. Our recommendations for organizations trying to improve cybersecurity in smart buildings can be found in our report, IoT Cybersecurity in the Built Environment.

In addition, our research found that while many IT professionals were aware of security and data privacy policies, facilities professionals were better versed in building codes, energy policies, and other compliance requirements for constructing new buildings. We educated smart building owners about current and future IoT policies in two white papers: IoT Policy Landscape: Implications for Managing Security in the Built Environment, and IoT Data Privacy: Managing and Anticipating Data Privacy in the Built Environment. These white papers provide an overview of IoT-related federal and state regulations that impact IoT in the built environment.

We also educated policymakers on the challenges building owners face with smart building cybersecurity in the white paper, IoT and Cybersecurity Risk: Core Issues for the Building Industry. This white paper provides policy makers with an overview of the organizational and cultural challenges that building owners face.

This research has developed a much more nuanced understanding of the technical and cultural disciplinary divides between IT and facilities, the challenges they face in working together with new IoT systems, and the ways of managing these challenges.  This is a new area of project management as IoT brings new cybersecurity challenges to owners that IT, facilities, and D&C professionals must understand and address.
